bestBHT.bht: A woman, known as a sinner in the city, approached Jesus during a meal hosted by a Pharisee. The Pharisee may not have had sinister motives in inviting Jesus, but became offended when Jesus showed compassion to the sinful woman. Recognizing the Pharisee's misguided judgment, Jesus accepted the invitation without hesitation. This encounter teaches us that Christ came to save those who are lost, and reminds us to approach questionable friendships with wisdom and grace, combining the innocence of the dove with the wisdom of the serpent.

Henry Alford: We must either render, ‘which was a sinner in the city,’ i.e. known as such in the place by public repute,—carrying on a sinful occupation in the place.
A woman which was in the city, a sinner.
The exact time and place are indeterminate.
Albert Barnes: Nothing more is known of him.
The notion of 'sitting' at meals is taken from modern customs, and was not practiced by the Jews.
Meat - Supper. Food of any kind.
John Calvin: But whatever might be his mildness, he is presently offended when he sees Christ bestow a gracious reception on a woman who, in his opinion, ought not to have been permitted to approach or to converse with him.
Simon’s mistake lies only in this: Not considering that Christ came to save what was lost, he rashly concludes that Christ does not distinguish between the worthy and the unworthy.
Let us learn, first, that Christ was given as a Deliverer to miserable and lost men, and to restore them from death to life.
Philip Schaff: Our Lord, who came ‘eating and drinking’ (Luke 7:34), accepted the invitation.
The sandals were usually removed before eating.
Archibald T. Robertson: The use of ινα after ερωταω is on the border between the pure object clause and the indirect question.
Luke has two other instances of Pharisees who invited Jesus to meals and he alone gives them. This is the Gospel of Hospitality.
It is not necessary to think this Pharisee had any sinister motive in his invitation though he was not overly friendly.
John Gill: This he did under a disguise of respect, and show of affection to him; though very likely with a design upon him to ensnare him, or take some advantage against him if he could."
He made no hesitation about it, but at once accepted of his invitation, though he knew both the man and his intentions; having nothing to fear from him."
Being willing to carry it courteously to all men, and give proof of what he had just now said of himself.
John Wesley: Let the candour with which our Lord accepted this invitation, and his gentleness and prudence at this ensnaring entertainment, teach us to mingle the wisdom of the serpent, with the innocence and sweetness of the dove.
Let us neither absolutely refuse all favours, nor resent all neglects, from those whose friendship is at best very doubtful, and their intimacy by no means safe.
Mingle the wisdom of the serpent, with the innocence and sweetness of the dove.

bhtAttempts.bht: A woman, known in the city as a sinner, approached Jesus during a meal hosted by a Pharisee. The exact details of this encounter are unclear, but it is evident that the Pharisee extended an invitation to Jesus, possibly out of genuine curiosity. Nonetheless, the Pharisee had an immediate negative reaction upon seeing Jesus show compassion to the sinful woman. He failed to recognize that Jesus came to save those who were lost, disregarding the fact that Christ had accepted the invitation without hesitation. In this situation, Jesus demonstrated both wisdom and grace, accepting the invitation while being aware of the Pharisee's intentions. It serves as a reminder to us to handle questionable friendships with caution, blending the wisdom of the serpent with the innocence and sweetness of the dove.

During a meal hosted by a Pharisee, a woman, known as a sinner in the city, approached Jesus. The Pharisee's motives for inviting Jesus may have been genuine, but he became offended when Jesus showed compassion to the sinful woman. Yet Jesus, aware of the Pharisee's intentions, accepted the invitation without hesitation. This encounter serves as a reminder for us to be cautious in questionable friendships, blending wisdom and grace as we navigate these relationships.

A woman, known as a sinner in the city, approached Jesus during a meal hosted by a Pharisee. The Pharisee may have invited Jesus without sinister motives, though he was not overly friendly. However, upon witnessing Jesus showing compassion to the sinful woman, the Pharisee became offended. In this situation, Jesus demonstrated wisdom and grace, accepting the invitation despite being aware of the Pharisee's intentions. This reminds us to handle questionable friendships with caution, blending the wisdom of the serpent with the innocence and sweetness of the dove.
